To Whom It May Concern:

We write in response to a letter from the Department of Health and Human Services dated November 21, 2017 (November 21 letter) [1] and received November 21, 2017, in response to our November 20, 2017 Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request (November 20 letter).[2] In our November 20 letter, we requested on behalf of our client, the Federation for American Immigration Reform (FAIR), both “representative of the news media requester” status and a public interest fee waiver. HHS’s November 21 letter classified FAIR as a “commercial use requester,” thus denying “representative of the news media requester” status, and denied FAIR a public interest fee waiver. As discussed below, we hereby appeal both findings.

  1. FAIR Has No Commercial Interest That Would Be Furthered by the Requested Disclosure.

FAIR does not meet the definition of commercial requester and, further, nowhere in the November 21 letter are there reasons stated for why FAIR has been labelled as such. FAIR is a nonprofit organization as defined under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code and does not seek this information for any commercial benefit. FAIR’s committed to protecting the public’s right to be aware of the immigration-related activities of government agencies and to ensuring the lawful and appropriate use of government funds by those agencies. Of the information requested, there is little possibility, let alone plans, of pursuing profitmaking opportunities. The information will be used to further the knowledge and interests of the general public regarding HHS’s disbursal this year alone of $448,107 to Farmworker Justice,[3] an organization that, as we mentioned in our November 20 letter, advocates for the extreme notion of amnesty for every single illegal immigrant in the country.

2. As FAIR Has No Commercial Interest in the Requested Information, There Is No Need to Balance a Commercial Interest Against the Public Interest in Disclosure.

As FAIR has no commercial interest in the requested information, there is no need to balance a commercial interest against the public interest in disclosure. Thus, this element, FAIR also satisfies.

3. Indeed, FOIA Officers throughout Department of Health and Human Services Have Regularly Granted FAIR Fee Waivers For Its Noncommercial Purposes.

We would refer you to Ms. Kimberly Epstein, FOIA Officer in HHS’s Administration for Children and Families, who in connection with our inquiries, often on issues associated with refugees and asylees, has for years regularly granted us noncommercial fee waivers, as in Administration for Children and Families FOIA Office Case Nos. 15-0322, 16-0253, 16-0265, 16-0273, 16-0280 and 16-0306. For an illustrative example, for Case No. 16-0306, Ms. Epstein’s office waived all fees to process over a thousand pages due to our noncommercial purposes. You may reach out to her office by phone at (202) 401-4829 or by email at FOIA@acf.hhs.gov.

If you do not understand this appeal or any portion thereof, or if you feel you require clarification of this appeal or any portion thereof, please contact Tyler Bass by email at tbass@irli.org or by telephone at (202) 232-5590. We look forward to the granting of this appeal and receiving the waiver of all costs. We await your prompt reply.
